{{About|the American figure skater|the Australian softball player|Tanya Harding}} {{excessive detail|date=September 2018}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox figure skater | name = Tonya Harding | image = File:Tonya harding mac club 1994 by andrew parodi.jpeg | caption = Harding at a [[Portland, Oregon]] reception shortly after the [[1994 Winter Olympics]] | country = {{USA}} | birth_name = Tonya Maxene Harding | fullname = Tonya Maxene Price | birth_date = {{nowrap| {{Birth date and age |1970|11|12}} }} | birth_place = [[Portland, Oregon]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | residence = | height = {{convert|5|ft|1|in|m}} | weight = | coach = Diane Rawlinson (1973–1989; 1992–1994)
Dody Teachman (1989–92) | skating club = | retired = | spouse = {{plainlist|*{{marriage|Jeff Gillooly
|1990|1993|end=div.}} *{{marriage|Michael Smith
|1995|1996|end=div.}} *{{marriage|Joseph Price
|2010}} }} | medaltemplates = {{MedalCountry | the USA}} {{MedalSport | Ladies' [[Figure skating]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[World Figure Skating Championships|World Championships]]}} {{MedalSilver| [[1991 World Figure Skating Championships|1991 Munich]]|Ladies' singles}} }} '''Tonya Maxene Price''' (née '''Harding'''; born November 12, 1970) is a retired American [[figure skating|figure skater]]. A native of [[Portland, Oregon]], Harding was raised primarily by her mother, who enrolled her in ice skating lessons beginning at age four. Harding would spend much of her early life training, eventually dropping out of high school to devote her time to the sport. After climbing the ranks in the [[U.S. Figure Skating Championships]] between 1986 and 1989, Harding won the 1989 [[Skate America]] competition. She was the 1991 and 1994 U.S. champion before being stripped of her 1994 title, and 1991 [[1991 World Figure Skating Championships|World silver medalist]]. In 1991, she earned distinction as being the first American woman to successfully land a triple [[Axel jump|Axel]] in competition, and the second woman to do so in history (behind [[Midori Ito]]). She is also a two-time Olympian and a two-time Skate America Champion. In January 1994, Harding became embroiled in controversy when her ex-husband, Jeff Gillooly, orchestrated an attack on fellow US Olympian [[Nancy Kerrigan]]. After the [[1994 Winter Olympics]], Harding ultimately pleaded guilty to hindering the prosecution on March 16 and was banned for life on June 30, 1994 from the [[U.S. Figure Skating Association]]. In the early 2000s, Harding competed as a [[professional boxer]], and her life has been the subject of numerous films, documentaries, books, and academic studies. In 2014, two [[Television documentary|documentary television films]] about Harding's life and skating career (''Nancy & Tonya'' and ''The Price of Gold'') were aired within two months of each other — inspiring [[Steven Rogers (screenwriter)|Steven Rogers]] to write the [[Black comedy|darkly comedic]] [[biographical film]] ''[[I, Tonya]]'', released in 2017 and starring [[Margot Robbie]] as Harding. In 2018, she was a contestant on [[Dancing with the Stars (U.S. season 26)|season 26]] of ''[[Dancing with the Stars (U.S. TV series)|Dancing with the Stars]]'', finishing in third place. == Early life == [[File:Ice chalet lloyd center portland oregon lec by andrew parodi.jpeg|thumb|Right|Ice Chalet at Portland's [[Lloyd Center]], where Harding began skating at age four]] Tonya Maxene Harding was born on November 12, 1970, in Portland, Oregon, to LaVona Golden and Albert Gordon Harding (1933–2009).{{cite web |url=https://www.tillamookheadlightherald.com/obituaries/albert-gordon-harding/article_fbf7f286-1e22-5e3d-8d4b-3c27f9952c35.html |title=Albert Gordon Harding |newspaper=Headlight-Herald|date=2009-04-14| accessdate=2018-01-20}} She was raised in [[East Portland, Oregon|East Portland]], and began skating at age three, training with coach Diane Rawlinson. During her youth, Harding also hunted, drag raced, and learned automotive mechanics from her father. LaVona struggled to support the family while working as a waitress, and hand-sewed her daughter's skating costumes as they could not afford to purchase them. Harding's parents divorced after 19 years of marriage in 1987, when she was 16 years old.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=dpNODgAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=They%20divorced%20in%201987|url-access=subscription|last1=Prouse|first1=Lynda D.|last2=Harding|first2=Tonya|title=The Tonya Tapes|year=2008|page=40|access-date=2018-08-03|quote=[My parents] divorced in 1987. They separated in February, and then their divorce was final sometime in the summer}} She later dropped out of [[Milwaukie High School]] during her sophomore year in order to focus on skating, and earned a General Equivalency Diploma.{{sfn|Prouse|Harding|2008|pages=13; 44; 46; 65}} According to Harding, she was frequently abused by her mother. She stated that by the time she was seven years old, both physical and psychological abuse had become a regular part of her life. LaVona admitted to one instance of hitting Harding at an ice rink.{{cite web |website=Oprah.com |url=http://www.oprah.com/world/Tonya-Hardings-Figure-Skating-Scandal/5 |title=Tonya Harding's Skating Scandal |access-date=2016-11-28}} In January 2018, Harding's childhood friend and filmmaker, Sandra Luckow, spoke in defence of Harding's mother because she felt that the 2017 film ''I, Tonya'' stretched some truths about LaVona's character. Luckow said that although Harding's mother could be "egregious" towards her daughter, LaVona actually funded and appreciated Harding's skating lessons – and had "a huge amount of humanity."{{cite magazine |url=https://people.com/movies/tonya-harding-mother-monster-friend/|first=Ale|last=Russian|title=Was Tonya Harding's Mom Really a Monster? Here's What Skater's Childhood Friend Has to Say|magazine=People|date=2018-01-27|accessdate=2018-07-30}}{{cite magazine|url=https://www.si.com/vault/1992/01/13/125774/not-your-average-ice-queen-a-troubled-past-hasnt-stopped-tonya-harding-from-becoming-a-figure-skating-champion|title=Not Your Average Ice Queen|magazine=Sports Illustrated|date=1992-01-13|accessdate=2018-08-02|quote=LaVona used the money she got in tips to pay for Tonya's lessons — $25 a week at first}}{{cite news |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1991-03-10/sports/9101220145_1_diane-rawlinson-tonya-harding-world-figure-skating-championships|title=Tonya Turns Tense, Tough Times To Triumphs |first=Phil |last=Hersh |newspaper=Chicago Tribune |date=1991-03-10|accessdate=2018-08-02|quote=LaVona Golden got 15 minutes off work as a restaurant cashier...to watch on television as her daughter became national champion. 'I saw her future right there,' Golden said. 'Now she can have everything she needs or wants. It won't be the way it was for us, not to have much of anything'.}} In Harding's 2008 authorized biography, ''The Tonya Tapes'' (written by Lynda D. Prouse from recorded interviews she had with Harding), she revealed she was the victim of acquaintance rape in 1991{{cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=dpNODgAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=I%20never%20told%20anybody%20because%20I%20knew%20the%20person|url-access=subscription|last1=Prouse|first1=Lynda D.|last2=Harding|first2=Tonya|title=The Tonya Tapes|year=2008|pages=125; 132|access-date=July 31, 2018|quote=I was separated from Jeff [at the] time in '91. I never told anybody because I knew the person. It was a friend of mine.}} and that her half-brother, Chris Davison, molested her on several occasions when she was a child. In 1986, Harding called the police after Davison had been sexually harassing and terrorizing her. He was arrested and spent a short time in prison. Harding claimed that her parents were in denial about Davison's behavior and told her not to press criminal charges against him. Davison was killed in a 1988 unsolved vehicular hit-and-run accident.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=dpNODgAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=.And%20my%20mother%20and%20father%20came%20home%20and%20said%20I%20was|url-access=subscription|last1=Prouse|first1=Lynda D.|last2=Harding|first2=Tonya|title=The Tonya Tapes|year=2008|pages=57–62|access-date=July 30, 2018|quote=[The police] ended up arresting [Davison]...And my mother and father came home and said I was [lying about the harassment].}}{{cite magazine|url=https://www.si.com/vault/1992/01/13/125774/not-your-average-ice-queen-a-troubled-past-hasnt-stopped-tonya-harding-from-becoming-a-figure-skating-champion|title=Not Your Average Ice Queen|magazine=Sports Illustrated|date=Jan 13, 1992|accessdate=2018-07-31}} On May 3, 1994, during an interview with [[Rolonda Watts]], Harding said that Chris Davison was the lone person in her life unworthy of forgiveness and "the only person I've ever hated."{{cite magazine|url=https://variety.com/1994/tv/news/rolonda-first-talker-to-nab-tonya-interview-120020/|title='Rolonda' first talker to nab Tonya interview|last=Flint|first=Joe|magazine=Variety|date=April 8, 1994|accessdate=2018-07-31}}[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=95rjRhjESUg&t=1012s Rolonda Watts' Interview with Tonya Harding]. ''Rolonda (1994-1997)''. May 1994 Excerpt of Rolonda Watts asking about Chris Davison's death and his abuse of Harding from 16:52 == Skating career == Harding trained as a figure skater throughout her youth with coach Diane Rawlinson. In the mid-1980s, she began working her way up the competitive skating ladder. She placed sixth at the 1986 U.S. Figure Skating Championships, fifth in 1987 and 1988, and third in 1989. After competing in the February [[1989 U.S. Figure Skating Championships|1989 Nationals Championship]], Harding began training with Dody Teachman as her coach.{{cite news |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1992-03-04/sports/9201200938_1_diane-rawlinson-dody-teachman-tonya-harding|title=Skater Changes Coaches, Again|first=Phil|last=Hersh|newspaper=Chicago Tribune |date=March 4, 1992|accessdate=2018-08-05}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=dpNODgAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=snippet&q=%22Who%20was%20your%20coach%22|url-access=subscription|last1=Prouse|first1=Lynda D.|last2=Harding|first2=Tonya|title=The Tonya Tapes|year=2008|page=26|access-date=2018-08-03|quote=Who was your coach...through your amateur years? *'Diane...then Dody Teachman was my other coach - when I came into my 18 year old teenage years thinking I knew everything...'*}} She then won the October [[1989 Skate America]] competition,{{cite newspaper|layurl=https://www.statelib.lib.in.us/IndyNews/1848_1991_display.asp?ID=123488|title=Skate America, major international figure skating coming to Indianapolis in October 1989|page=12|via=www.StateLib.lib.In.us (Indiana State Library)|department=Indianapolis Newspapers Database, 1848-1991|newspaper=The Indianapolis Star|date=Aug 20, 1989|postscript= : Section B, column 5}} and was considered a strong contender at the February [[1990 U.S. Figure Skating Championships]]. However, she was suffering from the [[influenza|flu]] and [[asthma]] and had a poor free skate. After the original program, she dropped from second place and finished seventh overall.{{sfn|Prouse|Harding|2008|pages=96-98}} Harding was a powerful free skater and typically had lower placements in the [[compulsory figures]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/17/sports/figure-skating-harding-takes-singles-title.html|title=Harding Takes Singles Title|first=Micheal|last=Janofsky|newspaper=New York Times|date=Feb 17, 1991|accessdate=2018-08-05}}{{cite news|url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1988/01/07/Figure-Skating-Results/3923568530000/|title=1988 U.S. Figure Skating Championships Results|department=Senior-level Ladies|agency=United Press International (UPI)|date=Jan 7, 1988|access-date=2018-07-27|quote=Tonya Harding ranked 8th out of 19th in Compulsory Figures}} Harding's breakthrough year came in 1991 when, at the [[1991 United States Figure Skating Championships|U.S. Championships]], she completed her first [[triple Axel]] in competition on February 16 — the first American woman to execute the jump.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/12/sports/figure-skating-a-triple-axel-with-rippling-effects.html |title=A Triple Axel With Rippling Effects |first=Michael |last=Janofsky |newspaper=New York Times |date=March 12, 1991|accessdate=2017-12-22}} She won the 1991 U.S. Ladies' Singles title with the event's first 6.0 technical merit score since [[Janet Lynn]]'s 1973 performance at the U.S. Championships. At the March 1991 World Championships, an international event, she again completed the triple Axel. Harding would finish second behind [[Kristi Yamaguchi]], and in front of Nancy Kerrigan, marking the first time one country swept the ladies medal podium at the [[World Figure Skating Championships]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/17/sports/figure-skating-skating-sweep-for-the-us-women.html|title=Skating Sweep for the U.S. Women|first=Michael|last=Janofsky|newspaper=New York Times|date=March 17, 1991|accessdate=2018-07-18}} At the September [[1991 Skate America]] competition, Harding recorded three more firsts: * The first woman to complete a triple Axel in the short program * The first woman to successfully execute two triple Axels in a single competition * The first ever to complete a triple Axel in combination (with the double [[toe loop]]) Despite these record-breaking performances, after 1991, Harding was never able to successfully complete the triple Axel in competition again; her competitive results began to decline. She and Dody Teachman had briefly parted ways in April 1991, but had reunited in June; Harding was still training under Teachman for the upcoming 1992 season. She placed third in the January [[1992 U.S. Figure Skating Championships]] despite twisting her ankle during practice, and finished fourth in the February [[1992 Winter Olympics]]. On March 1, 1992, Harding gave Teachman a summary dismissal and returned to Diane Rawlinson to be coached by her.{{cite news|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1992-03-08/sports/9201220344_1_diane-rawlinson-dody-teachman-tonya-harding|title=Adulation On Hold For Tonya Harding|first=Phil|last=Hersh|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=March 8, 1992|accessdate=2018-07-13}} On March 29 Harding placed sixth in the [[1992 World Figure Skating Championships|1992 World Championships]], although she had a better placement at the November [[1992 Skate Canada International]] event finishing fourth.{{cite web|url=https://www.onthisday.com/date/1992/march/29 |title=What Happened on March 29, 1992|website=OnThisDay.com (Today in History Archives)|department=Ladies Figure Skating Championship in Oakland won by Kristi Yamaguchi|editor-last=Graham|editor-first=James|orig-year=2000|accessdate=2018-08-05|postscript= → Kristi Yamaguchi would have won the event on the same day as the other Ladies' Singles free skate}}{{sfn|Haight|Vader|1994|p=35}} In the 1993 season, she skated poorly in the U.S. Championships and failed to qualify for the World Championship team. In 1994, Harding won the U.S. Championships, but was later stripped of her title because of her involvement in the attack on Nancy Kerrigan. Kerrigan was unable to participate in the U.S. Championships due to her injury. Despite the legal controversy,{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/05/sports/olympics-ioc-official-says-harding-should-skate.html|title=I.O.C. Official Says Harding Should Skate|first=Jere|last=Longman|newspaper=New York Times|date=Feb 5, 1994|accessdate=2018-07-16}}{{cite news|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1994-02-13/news/9402130126_1_games-administrative-board-olympic-movement-and-sportsmanship-usoc-decision|title=Settlement Means Harding Will Skate|first=Phil|last=Hersh|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=Feb 13, 1994|accessdate=2018-07-16}} Harding was permitted to remain a member of the U.S. ice skating team at the 1994 Winter Olympics in [[Lillehammer]], [[Norway]]. After an issue with a broken skate lace, she was given a re-skate in the long program and finished in eighth place, far behind [[Oksana Baiul]] (gold) and Nancy Kerrigan (silver).{{cite news|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/tonya-harding/1994/02/1994_winter_olympics_tonya_har.html|title=Tonya Harding finishes 8th in women's figure skating|work=OregonLive.com|access-date=2018-05-01|language=en-US}} === Figure skating record === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! colspan="10" style="background:#ffdead; text-align:center;" | '''International''' |- ! However, the competition results were not changed and the title was left vacant rather than moving all the other competitors up one position.{{cite news |title=U.S. Title Is Taken Back From Harding |agency=Associated Press |newspaper=New York Times|date=July 1, 1994 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/07/01/sports/figure-skating-us-title-is-taken-back-from-harding.html |accessdate=2010-09-28}} == Attack on Nancy Kerrigan and aftermath == On {{start date|1994|1|6}}, one day before the [[1994 United States Figure Skating Championships|U.S. Figure Skating Championship]] first Ladies' Singles competition, [[Nancy Kerrigan]] was attacked after a practice session at the Detroit [[Cobo Center|Cobo Arena]]. The assailant was Shane Stant, contracted to break her right leg. Stant and his uncle, Derrick Smith, were hired for this [[assault]] by Harding's ex-husband, Jeff Gillooly, and her one-time bodyguard, Shawn Eckardt.[https://sportsworld.nbcsports.com/nancy-tonya/]. ''NBC SportsWorld''. ''Nancy & Tonya'' (2014) documentary. Tonya telling a reporter "Shawn is my bodyguard" while he walks beside her on January 10, 1994 - time code ca 0:29:14 After failing to find Kerrigan at her Massachusetts training rink, Stant had taken a 20-hour bus trip to Detroit.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/01/23/sports/figure-skating-traveling-far-and-lying-low-to-get-nancy-kerrigan.html|title=Traveling Far and Lying Low to Get Nancy Kerrigan|work=New York Times|first=Joseph B. |last=Treaster|date=Jan 23, 1994|accessdate=2018-07-09}} Nancy Kerrigan was walking behind a curtain to a corridor when Stant rushed behind her. Using both hands, he then swung a 21-inch [[ASP, Inc.|ASP]] [[telescopic baton]] at her right leg, striking her above the knee. The intent was preventing her competing in both the National Championships (Kerrigan was the defending [[1993 U.S. Figure Skating Championships|1993 U.S. Ladies' Champion]]) and the Winter Olympics. Kerrigan's leg was not broken but severely bruised, forcing her to withdraw from the Championships and forgo competing to retain the U.S. Ladies' title.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/01/07/sports/figure-skating-kerrigan-attacked-after-practice-assailant-flees.html|title=Kerrigan Attacked After Practice; Assailant Flees |work=New York Times|first=Jere|last=Longman|date=Jan 7, 1994|accessdate=2018-07-11}} On January 8, Harding won the U.S. Ladies' Singles title; she and Kerrigan were then both selected for the [[United States at the 1994 Winter Olympics|1994 Olympic team]]. On February 1, Gillooly's attorney negotiated a [[plea bargain]] in exchange for testimony regarding all involved parties in the attack. He was sentenced in July after publicly apologizing to Kerrigan – even though, he said, "any apology coming from me rings hollow."{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1994-02-02/news/mn-18226_1_2-year-prison-term|title=Ex-Spouse Pleads Guilty & Implicates Harding|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|first=John|last=Balzar|date=Feb 2, 1994|access-date=2018-07-07}}{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/07/14/sports/figure-skating-gillooly-sentenced-to-2-years-in-jail.html|title=Gillooly Sentenced to 2 Years in Jail|newspaper=New York Times|agency=Associated Press|date=July 14, 1994|access-date=July 24, 2018}} Gillooly and Eckardt pleaded guilty to [[Racket (crime)|racketeering]], Stant and Smith (who drove Stant in the [[Crime scene getaway|getaway car]] and funneled money) pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit second-degree assault — all served prison time.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/05/17/sports/figure-skating-kerrigan-attacker-and-accomplice-sent-to-jail.html |title=Kerrigan Attacker & Accomplice Sent to Jail |newspaper=New York Times|date=May 17, 1994 |access-date=2016-11-28}}{{cite news |url=https://www.oregonlive.com/tonya-harding/2014/01/tonya_harding-nancy_kerrigan_2.html|title=20 years later: highlights in a timeline|last=Muldoon |first=Katy|date=Jan 6, 2014|newspaper=The Oregonian|accessdate=2018-06-25}} Judge Donald Londer noted the attack could have injured Kerrigan more seriously.{{cite news |url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1994/07/13/Gillooly-sentenced-in-Kerrigan-attack/5068774072000|title=Gillooly sentenced in Kerrigan attack|newspaper=United Press International (UPI)|date=July 13, 1994|access-date=2018-07-24}} On February 25, Harding finished eighth in the Olympics; Nancy Kerrigan, having recovered from her injury, won the [[Olympic medal|Olympic silver medal]] behind Oksana Baiul from [[Ukraine]]. Eckardt was released from prison in September 1995 and changed his name to Brian Sean Griffith; he died at age 40 on December 12, 2007.{{cite web |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20071215/ap_on_re_us/obit_griffith |title=Player in attack on Kerrigan dies at 40 |website=Yahoo News |date=Dec 15, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071218172722/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20071215/ap_on_re_us/obit_griffith |archivedate=Dec 18, 2007 |deadurl=yes}} [[File:Tonya Harding Olympic practice at Clackamas Town Center 1994 3.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1|Harding's practice sessions at [[Clackamas Town Center]], in preparation for the 1994 Winter Olympics, were attended by thousands of spectators and dozens of reporters and film crews]] On January 11, 1994, [[Ann Schatz]] interviewed Harding at the [[KOIN|KOIN-TV]] station in Portland, Oregon. Schatz asked if she had considered whether someone she knew had planned to attack Nancy. Harding answered "I have definitely thought about it. No one controls my life but me...if there’s something in there that I don’t like, I’m going to change it."{{cite news|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SCS19940113.1.12&srpos=32&e=-------en--20--21-byDA-txt-txIN-%22tonya+harding%22-------1|format=TIFF|title=Husband, bodyguard implicated in attack - Police 'close' to arrest in Kerrigan case|last1=Bruscas|first1=Angelo|last2=Clever|first2=Dick |newspaper=Santa Cruz Sentinel|volume=137|number=12|date=Jan 13, 1994|accessdate=2018-08-12}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=4R06DwAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=discredit|url-access=subscription|last1=Haight|last2=Vader|first2=J.E. |first1=Abby|title=Fire on Ice|year=1994|page=99|access-date=2018-08-12|quote='I just wish people would see that, you know, I’m out there trying just as much as everybody else is, and it’s just really sad. It’s sad that there’s that kind of people out there.' And she once again expressed her fierce determination. 'No one controls my life but me,' Harding said.}}[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OGdpgWCTSug&t=56s Ann Schatz's 1994 interview with Tonya Harding at KOIN]. ''KOIN 6''. January 11, 1994 Excerpt of Tonya Harding claiming that she doesn't know how Nancy Kerrigan came to be attacked from 0:56 Harding also confirmed she had spoken with [[FBI]] agents while in Detroit and again in Portland.{{cite news|url=https://www.oregonlive.com/tonya-harding/1994/01/fbi_investigating_tonya_hardin.html|title=FBI investigating Tonya Harding's husband as part of alleged plot to sideline figure skater Nancy Kerrigan|last1=Long|first1=James|last2=Hogan|first2=Dave|last3=Haight|first3=Abby|newspaper=The Oregonian|date=Jan 12, 1994|accessdate=2018-08-13}} On January 13, Eckardt and Smith were arrested – Stant surrendered to an FBI office the next day.{{cite news |url=https://www.oregonlive.com/tonya-harding/1994/01/sheriffs_deputies_arrest_tonya.html|title=Sheriff's deputies arrest Tonya Harding's bodyguard & another man in Nancy Kerrigan attack|last1=Long |first1=James |last2=Hogan |first2=Dave |date=Jan 14, 1994 |newspaper=The Oregonian|accessdate=2018-08-13}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/01/14/us/police-in-oregon-make-arrests-in-assault-on-olympic-skater.html|title=Police in Oregon Make Arrests In Assault on Olympic Skater|first=Timothy|last=Egan |newspaper=New York Times |date=Jan 14, 1994|accessdate=July 13, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/longterm/olympics1998/history/timeline/articles/time_011594.htm|first=William|last=Hamilton|title=Three Held in Assault on Kerrigan|newspaper=Washington Post|date=Jan 15, 1994|accessdate=Aug 13, 2018}} On January 14, the [[United States Figure Skating Association|USFSA]] made a statement regarding whether Eckardt's arrest affected Harding's place on the U.S. Olympic team: "we will deal only with the facts."{{cite news|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SCS19940114.1.13&srpos=1&e=-------en--20--1-byDA-txt-txIN-%22Speculation+where+it+involves+the+careers+of+young+athletes+is+pointless%22-------1|format=TIFF|title=Harding keeps Olympic spot - for now|agency=Associated Press|newspaper=Santa Cruz Sentinel|volume=137|number=13|date=Jan 14, 1994|accessdate=Aug 12, 2018}} Harding and Gillooly's lawyers publicly confirmed the couple were in daily contact and cooperation with law enforcement.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=4R06DwAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage|url-access=subscription|last1=Haight|last2=Vader|first2=J.E.|first1=Abby|title=Fire on Ice|year=1994|page=100|access-date=Aug 13, 2018|quote=On Thursday, January 13, Dennis Rawlinson, Harding’s lawyer (and husband of Tonya’s coach), said that she would have plenty to say. The next day, a statement was issued: “Tonya Harding and Jeff Gillooly are meeting today with their lawyers...[They] have cooperated with law enforcement}} On January 15, Harding and Gillooly spoke with reporters, but declined to comment about the investigation.{{cite news|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SCS19940116.1.14&srpos=39&e=-------en--20--21-byDA-txt-txIN-%22tonya+harding%22-------1|format=TIFF|title=Harding chances called 'grim' - New witness says skater knew of plot|last=Wilstein|first=Steve|newspaper=Santa Cruz Sentinel|volume=137|number=15|date=Jan 16, 1994|accessdate=2018-08-13}} On January 16, Harding's attorney read a [[press-conference|news conference]] statement on her behalf, denying involvement in Kerrigan's attack.{{cite news|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SCS19940117.1.1&srpos=42&e=-------en--20--41-byDA-txt-txIN-%22tonya+harding%22-------1|format=TIFF|title=Harding says she's innocent - 'Tonya is shocked & angry'|last=Wilstein|first=Steve|newspaper=Santa Cruz Sentinel|volume=137|number=16|date=Jan 17, 1994|accessdate=2018-08-13}} Harding left her home that evening to practice figure skating with her coaches, where she spoke with reporters and performed a triple Axel.{{cite news|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SCS19940118.1.28&srpos=49&e=-------en--20--41-byDA-txt-txIN-%22tonya+harding%22-------1|format=TIFF|title=Harding's ex-husband faces arrest|agency=Associated Press|newspaper=Santa Cruz Sentinel|volume=137|number=17|date=Jan 18, 1994 |accessdate=2018-08-13}} On January 18, 1994, Harding submitted to questioning by the district attorney and FBI, with her lawyers.{{cite news|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SCS19940119.1.23&srpos=52&e=-------en--20--41-byDA-txt-txIN-%22tonya+harding%22-------1|format=TIFF|title=Officials question Harding|agency=Associated Press|newspaper=Santa Cruz Sentinel|volume=137|number=18|date=Jan 19, 1994 |accessdate=2018-08-13}}{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1994-01-19/sports/sp-13203_1_tonya-harding|title=Harding Talks to FBI: Interrogation lasts into night. Skater announces split with ex-husband|first=John|last=Balzar|newspaper=LA Times|date=1994-01-19|accessdate=2018-08-13}} She was interviewed for over 10 hours – 8 hours into the interview, her lawyer issued a statement announcing her separation from Jeff Gillooly: "I continue to believe that Jeff is innocent of any wrongdoing. I wish him nothing but the best."{{cite news|last=Adams|first=Jane Meredith|title=Harding's Controlling Force|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1994-01-21/news/9401210113_1_harding-and-gillooly-jeff-gillooly-rival-skater-nancy-kerrigan|accessdate=2018-07-08|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=Jan 21, 1994}} Her full FBI transcript was press released on February 1. ''[[The Seattle Times]]'' reported the transcript stating that Harding had "changed her story well into a long interview...After hours of denying any involvement in trying to [[Cover-up|cover up]] the plot, an FBI agent finally 'told [her] that he knew she had lied to him, that he would tell her exactly how she had lied to him'."{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/01/19/sports/figure-skating-harding-stands-firm-in-9-hour-meeting.html|title=Harding Stands Firm In 9-Hour Meeting|first=Micheal|last=Janofsky|newspaper=New York Times|date=Jan 19, 1994|accessdate=2018-09-13}}{{cite news|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19940202&slug=1893162|agency=S.T. The interview ended with this comment from Harding: 'I’m telling on someone I really care about.'}} On January 19, Jeff Gillooly surrendered to the FBI.{{cite news |last=Brennan|first=Christine|title=Rival Skater's Ex-Husband Charged in Attack|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/longterm/olympics1998/history/timeline/articles/time_012094.htm|accessdate=Aug 14, 2018|newspaper=Washington Post|date=Jan 20, 1994}} On January 20, [[Diane Sawyer]] asked Harding on ''[[Primetime (U.S. TV program)|Primetime Live]]'' about the ongoing criminal investigation. Harding's close friend, with whom she was living, spoke to reporters on her behalf: "[Tonya] was shocked, very hurt…She was believing in [Jeff], what he was saying."{{cite news|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SCS19940127.1.1&srpos=70&e=-------en--20--61-byDA-txt-txIN-%22tonya+harding%22-------1|format=TIFF|title='Walls are closing in' on skater (1)|first=Bob|last=Baum|newspaper=Santa Cruz Sentinel|volume=137|number=26|date=Jan 27, 1994|accessdate=Aug 15, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SCS19940127.1.10&srpos=1&e=-------en--20--1-byDA-txt-txIN-%22she+was+believing+in+him%22+%22tonya+harding%22-------1|format=TIFF|title='Walls are closing in' on skater (2)|first=Bob|last=Baum|newspaper=Santa Cruz Sentinel|volume=137|number=26|date=Jan 27, 1994|accessdate=July 13, 2018}}{{cite magazine|url=https://www.newsweek.com/tonya-harding-i-know-people-who-love-me-190276|first=Patricia|last=King|title=Tonya Harding: 'I Know The People Who Love Me'|magazine=Newsweek|date=Feb 20, 1994 |accessdate=Aug 15, 2018}} Harding later held an 11am press-conference to read a prepared statement. She said she was sorry Nancy Kerrigan was attacked, that she respected Nancy, and claimed not to know in advance of the plot to disable her. Harding then publicly [[Acceptance of responsibility|took responsibility]] "for failing to report things [about the planned assault] when I returned home from Nationals [on January 10]...my [[Omission (law)|failure to immediately report]] this information is not a crime."{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/longterm/olympics1998/history/timeline/articles/time_012894.htm|title=Harding Admits Knowing of Plot After the Attack|first=Johnette|last=Howard|newspaper=Washington Post |date=Jan 28, 1994 |accessdate=July 6, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/sports/1994/01/28/text-of-tonya-hardings-statement/ccff4333-d36d-478d-939e-5a23b175727c/|title=Text of Tonya Harding's Statement|newspaper=Washington Post |date=Jan 28, 1994 |accessdate=July 24, 2018}} Many state laws including [[Oregon]] certify that the act of concealing criminal knowledge alone is not a crime.{{cite web|url=http://www.yossithecriminallawyer.com/concealing-an-offence/|title=Concealing an Offence|website=YossiTheCriminalLawyer.com|department=Blog|date=July 3, 2013|first= Yossi|last=Schochet|accessdate=July 31, 2018|quote=In the U.S. almost every State has rejected criminal prosecution for [[misprision of felony]], primarily for policy reasons, as it encroaches on civil liberties. An exception is the state of South Carolina.}} Nancy Kerrigan's attack had received a lot of publicity; [[news media]] crews had camped outside her home.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/longterm/olympics1998/history/timeline/articles/time_011594.htm|first=William|last=Hamilton|title=Three Held in Assault on Kerrigan|newspaper=Washington Post|date=Jan 15, 1994|accessdate=Aug 16, 2018}} The story was on the covers of ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'', ''[[Newsweek]]'', and ''[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]'' in January 1994.{{cite journal|last1=Martin|first1=Adam|last2=McDonald |first2=Mary G.|url=https://www.worc.ac.uk/gjseper/documents/Covering_womens_sport_An_analysis_of_Sports_Illustrated_covers_2012_1_81-97.pdf|format=PDF|title=Covering women's sport? An analysis of ''Sports Illustrated'' covers from 1987-2009|date=2012 |department=RESULTS - Are there any significant trends in coverage?|journal=Graduate Journal of Sport, Exercise & Physical Education Research|volume=1|page=91|issn=2046-9357|accessdate=Aug 14, 2018|quote=The theme of 'women’s sport as tragic' appeared as a phenomenon among ''Sports Illustrated'' magazine covers in 1993 & 1994. Kerrigan]] cover referencing the physical attack}} There was now much speculation about Harding's own alleged involvement in the assault plot.{{cite magazine |url=http://content.time.com/time/subscriber/article/0,33009,980059-1,00.html|title=What Did Tonya Know?|last=Smolowe |first=J|magazine=Time|date=1994-01-31|accessdate=2017-07-07}}{{cite news| 4, 1994|accessdate=July 12, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/03/17/sports/sports-of-the-times-harding-s-guilty-plea-anticlimactic.html|first=George|last=Vecsey|title=Harding's Guilty Showdown|newspaper=Washington Post|date=Feb 23, 1994|accessdate=Aug 14, 2018}} Abby Haight and J.E. Vader, journalists for ''[[The Oregonian]]'', wrote a [[biography]] of Harding called ''Fire on Ice'', which included excerpts of her January 18 FBI interview.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/retropolis/wp/2018/01/06/as-crazy-as-it-was-reporters-recall-the-nancy-kerrigan-tonya-harding-feeding-frenzy/|first=Jacob |last=Bogage|title='As crazy as it was': Reporters recall the Tonya Harding-Nancy Kerrigan feeding frenzy |newspaper=Washington Post |date=Jan 8, 2018|accessdate=July 6, 2018}} News media began regularly attending Harding's Portland practices, and unwelcomely recorded footage of her on February 7, running barefoot to stop a tow truck from hauling her illegally parked [[Pickup truck|pickup]].{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/sports/1994/02/09/portland-city-under-seige/90e1cfc6-3b86-40a6-9934-6b50c9c0e9ae/|first=Serge F.|last=Kovaleski|title=Portland: City Under Seige|newspaper=Washington Post|date=Feb 9, 1994|accessdate=2018-08-16}} On February 10, [[Connie Chung]] interviewed Harding. When asked about Gillooly, Harding said "I never did anything to hurt [Jeff]. If I ever did anything, it was to stick up for him and protect him."{{cite journal|last1=Benoit|first1=William L.|last2=Hanczor|first2=Robert S.|url=https://vdocuments.site/the-tonya-harding-controversy-an-analysis-of-image-restoration-strategies.html|format=TIFF|title=The Tonya Harding controversy: An analysis of image restoration strategies|date=Fall 1994|journal=[[Communication Quarterly]]|volume=42|issue=4|page=424|doi=10.1080/01463379409369947 |accessdate=2018-09-07}} Chung also negotiated to fly on the same airplane with Harding to [[Oslo]], leaving on February 15, and interviewed her again in Norway. Chung admitted she would not have travelled to Norway were it not for the scandal.{{cite news|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SCS19940216.1.14&srpos=138&e=-------en--20--121-byDA-txt-txIN-%22tonya+harding%22-------1|format=TIFF|title=Tonya hitting town - Kerrigan won't be in hugging mood|last=Rosen|first=Karen|newspaper=Santa Cruz Sentinel|volume=137|number=46|date=Feb 16, 1994|accessdate=Aug 14, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/22/sports/tv-sports-thirty-seconds-over-lillehammer-on-air-tonya.html|first=Richard|last=Sandomir|title=Thirty Seconds Over Lillehammer on Air Tonya|newspaper=New York Times |date=Feb 22, 1994|accessdate=Aug 14, 2018}} The media frenzy continued on February 17, when Nancy Kerrigan and Harding shared the ice at a practice session in the [[Hamar Olympic Amphitheatre]]. Approximately 400 members of the press were there to document this practice.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/longterm/olympics1998/history/timeline/articles/time_021894.htm|first=Christine |last=Brennan|title=Harding, Kerrigan Practice Together Under Scrutiny|newspaper=Washington Post|date=Feb 18, 1994|accessdate=July 16, 2018}} [[Scott Hamilton (figure skater)|Scott Hamilton]] believed the sport was depicted as a "tabloid event."{{sfn|Hamilton|1999|p=561}} It was noted that Nancy Kerrigan chose to wear the same skating costume at the practice session that she was wearing on January 6.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/18/sports/winter-olympics-for-practice-a-two-ring-circus-in-one-rink.html|first=Jere|last=Longman|title=For Practice, a Two-Ring Circus in One Rink|newspaper=New York Times |date=Feb 18, 1994|accessdate=Aug 14, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SCS19940218.1.15&srpos=1&e=-------en--20--1-byDA-txt-txIN-%22a+subtle+reminder+to+tonya%22-------1|format=TIFF|title=Tension on ice - Kerrigan, Harding quietly share Olympic practice space|agency=Associated Press|newspaper=Santa Cruz Sentinel|volume=137|number=48|date=1994-02-18|accessdate=2018-08-14}} Kerrigan later confirmed that her choice of dress that day was deliberate: "[[Humour]] is good, it's empowering."[https://sportsworld.nbcsports.com/nancy-tonya/]. Nancy Kerrigan explaining her decision to wear the same white skating costume on February 17, 1994 - time code ca 0:43:16 The tape-delayed broadcast of the February 23 Ladies' Olympic technical program remains one of the most watched telecasts in American history.{{cite magazine|url=http://www.variety.com/index.asp?layout=chart_pass&charttype=chart_topshowsalltime|magazine=Variety|author=Nielsen Media Research|title=Top 100 TV Shows of All Time|date=Aug 6, 2000|accessdate=2018-07-26|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090315021343/http://www.variety.com/index.asp?layout=chart_pass&charttype=chart_topshowsalltime|archivedate=March 15, 2009}}{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/24/business/the-media-business-winter-olympics-ratings-on-record-pace-for-cbs.html|first=Richard|last=Sandomir|title=Winter Olympics Ratings On Record Pace for CBS |newspaper=New York Times|date=Feb 24, 1994|accessdate=July 17, 2018}} [[File:Hamar crop.jpg|thumb|Hamar crop|Figure skating competitions for the 1994 Winter Olympics were held in the [[CC Amfi]], formerly known as the Hamar Olympic Amphitheatre.]] On February 5, 1994, the disciplinary panel of the U.S. Figure Skating Association stated that [[Reasonable suspicion|reasonable grounds]] existed to believe Harding had violated the sport's [[Ethical code|code of ethics]].{{cite web |url=https://www.scribd.com/document/222926632/Harding-v-USOC-Exhibit-USFSA-Disciplinary-Charges|title=Harding's Disciplinary Charges|website=Scribd |date=1994-02-05|accessdate=2018-08-27}} Her admitted failure to report information about an assault on a fellow competitor, supported by her FBI interview transcripts, resulted in Harding being [[Professional ethics|formally charged]] with "[making] false statements about her knowledge." The panel also recommended that she face a disciplinary hearing. [[Claire Waters Ferguson|Claire Ferguson]], president of the USFSA, decided not to suspend Harding's membership before any hearing took place. If Harding had been suspended, she likely still would have competed at the Winter Olympics after filing an [[injunction]] on the USFSA and asserting her rights under the [[Amateur Sports Act of 1978]].{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/01/28/sports/figure-skating-harding-to-get-olympic-spot-but-inquiry-continues.html|title=Harding to Get Olympic Spot but Inquiry Continues|newspaper=New York Times|first=Jere|last=Longman|date=Jan 28, 1994|access-date=2018-07-31}} Evidence examined by the panel included the testimonies of Stant and Smith, Harding and Gillooly's telephone records, and notes found in a Portland saloon trash receptacle on January 30.{{cite web|url=https://bleacherreport.com/articles/1887592-harding-kerrigan-20-years-later-remembering-the-stunning-life-changing-attack|first=Matt|last=Crossman|title=Harding-Kerrigan 20 Years Later: Remembering the Stunning Attack|department=The Evidence in the Dumpster|website=Bleacher Report, Inc|date=Dec 19, 2013|accessdate=July 20, 2018}} Harding was given 30 days to respond.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/06/sports/winter-olympics-harding-ordered-to-appear-at-hearing.html|title=Harding Ordered To Appear At Hearing|newspaper=New York Times|first=Jere|last=Longman|date=Feb 6, 1994|access-date=July 20, 2018}} On March 9, Judge [[Owen M. Panner|Owen Panner]] granted her a requested [[Stay of proceedings|halt]] on the 30-day deadline to delay her disciplinary hearing until June 27.{{cite web |url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/210813255/USFSA-s-decision-regarding-Tonya-Harding |title=USFSA's decision regarding Tonya Harding |website=Scribd |date=June 30, 1994 |accessdate=July 4, 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1994/03/22/jury-harding-in-on-plot/966b6613-14e9-4fcd-a2fc-c585deb3f4fc/|title=Jury: Harding in on Plot|newspaper=Washington Post|first=Johnette|last=Howard|date=March 22, 1994|access-date=July 24, 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/03/11/sports/a-clear-path-for-harding.html|title=Clear Path for Harding|newspaper=New York Times|date=1994-03-11|access-date=2018-07-21}} Meanwhile, Portland authorities stated the criminal investigation would conclude by March 21 with any [[indictment]]s and a [[Grand juries in the United States|grand jury]] report to be made at that time.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/longterm/olympics1998/history/timeline/articles/time_021594.htm|title=Thousands Watch Harding's Final Portland Workout|newspaper=Washington Post|first=Christine|last=Spolar|date=Feb 15, 1994|access-date=July 21, 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/03/20/sports/figure-skating-harding-deal-handed-something-to-both-sides.html|title=Harding Deal Handed Something to Both Sides|newspaper=New York Times|first=Jere|last=Longman|date=March 20, 1994|access-date=July 24, 2018}} On March 16, 1994, Harding pleaded guilty to [[Obstruction of justice|conspiracy to hinder prosecution]] as a [[Classes of offenses under United States federal law|Class C felony offense]] at a [[Multnomah County]] court hearing. She and her lawyer, Robert Weaver, negotiated a plea bargain ensuring no further prosecution.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/longterm/olympics1998/history/timeline/articles/time_031794.htm|title=Harding Admits Guilt in Plea Bargain, Avoids Prison|newspaper=Washington Post|first=Johnette|last=Howard|date=March 17, 1994|access-date=July 23, 2018}} Judge Donald Londer conducted routine questioning to make certain Harding understood her agreement, that she was entering her plea "knowingly and voluntarily." Harding told Londer she was. Her plea admissions were [[Knowledge (legal construct)|knowing]] of the assault plot after the fact, settling on a cover story with Gillooly and Eckardt on January 10, witnessing payphone calls to Smith affirming the story on January 10 and 11, and lying to FBI with the story on January 18.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/longterm/olympics1998/history/timeline/articles/time_020294.htm|title=Gillooly Pleads Guilty, Says Harding Approved Plot|last=Buckley|first=Stephen|date=Feb 2, 1994|newspaper=Washington Post|accessdate=June 23, 2018}}{{cite news |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1994-02-02/news/9402020823_1_nancy-kerrigan-tonya-harding-eckardt|title=Harding's ex-husband says she helped to plan attack - Attorney: 'What Did Tonya Know And When?'|date=Feb 2, 1994|newspaper=Orlando Sentinel|accessdate=June 24, 2018}} Law enforcement investigators had been following and videotaping the co-conspirators since January 10; they knew about the payphone calls.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/longterm/olympics1998/history/timeline/articles/time_012394.htm|department=Chronology of Kerrigan Attack|title=Tonya Harding Remains the Public Enigma|last=Brennan|first=Christine|date=Jan 23, 1994|newspaper=Washington Post|accessdate=Aug 2, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/01/sports/figure-skating-lawyer-for-skater-s-ex-husband-says-he-has-tied-her-to-attack.html|title=Lawyer for Skater's Ex-Husband Says He Has Tied Her to Attack|newspaper=New York Times|first=Michael|last=Janofsky|date=Feb 1, 1994|accessdate=Aug 2, 2018}} Her penalties included 3 years of [[probation]], $100,000 [[Fine (penalty)|fine]], and 500 hours [[community service]]. She agreed to reimburse Multnomah County $10,000 in legal expenses, undergo a [[Psychiatric assessment|psychiatric examination]], and volunteered to give $50,000 to the [[Special Olympics]] Oregon (SOOR) charity.{{cite web |url=http://www.soor.org/Sub-Page.aspx?name=About-Special-Olympics-Oregon&PID=2|title=Special Olympics Oregon|website=Soor.org |accessdate=July 24, 2018}} Oregon [[sentencing guidelines]] carried a max penalty of 5-years-prison for the offense.{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1994-03-17/news/mn-35216_1_figure-skating-team|title=Harding Pleads Guilty to Obstructing Justice. fees.{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/longterm/olympics1998/history/timeline/articles/time_020294a.htm|first=Mark|last=Asher|title=Nike Steps Up With $25,000 for Harding's Skating Championships|World Championships]] (for which she was scheduled to leave tomorrow).{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/03/17/sports/figure-skating-judge-accepts-harding-plea-in-conspiracy.html|title=Judge Accepts Harding Plea In Conspiracy|newspaper=New York Times|first=Michael|last=Janofsky|date=March 17, 1994|access-date=July 23, 2018}} District attorney Norman Frink stated that if Harding had not agreed to the plea, "we would have proceeded with an indictment on all possible charges...punishment was taking away [skating] privilege."{{cite news |url=https://www.oregonlive.com/tonya-harding/2014/01/tonya_harding-nancy_kerrigan_h.html|title=Harding found guilty of hindering investigation |last1=Long |first1=James |last2=Hogan |first2=Dave |date=March 17, 1994 |newspaper=The Oregonian|accessdate=June 23, 2018}} Weaver said the plea agreement was satisfactory to Harding, partly because she avoided prison. Regarding [[Right to a fair trial|trial]] concerns, he stated "we would have prevailed at trial."{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/03/18/sports/figure-skating-harding-plea-bargain-is-called-a-time-saver.html|title=Harding Plea Bargain Is Called a Time-Saver|last=Janofsky|first=Michael|date=March 18, 1994|newspaper=New York Times|accessdate=June 24, 2018}} An executive of the USFSA commented "[We] don't know if Tonya is innocent or guilty...if [she was involved before] the national championship."{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/03/17/sports/figure-skating-skating-group-is-angry-kerrigan-is-silent.html|title=Skating Group Is Angry; Kerrigan Is Silent|last=Longman|first=Jere|date=March 17, 1994|newspaper=New York Times|accessdate=June 24, 2018}} On March 18, Claire Ferguson decided Harding's disciplinary hearing would still proceed in June. The USFSA's executive committee convened to discuss their position should Harding seek reinstatement and whether they might strip her of the 1994 National Championship title. Neither issue was decided at that time.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/03/18/sports/figure-skating-skating-association-schedules-hearing-in-june-on-harding.html|title=Skating Association Schedules Hearing in June on Harding|last=Longman|first=Jere|date=March 18, 1994|newspaper=New York Times|accessdate=June 24, 2018}} [[File:Tonya harding returning from norway 1994.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1|Harding arriving at [[Portland International Airport]] amid a crush of reporters after the 1994 Olympics]] On March 21, 1994, a Portland grand jury issued an indictment stating there was evidence Harding participated in the attack plot. The indictment concluded more than two months of investigation and witness testimonies from Diane Rawlinson, Erika Bakacs (Harding's choreographer), Eckardt's college instructor and classmates, and Vera Marano (a freelance figure skating writer in Philadelphia).{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/longterm/olympics1998/history/timeline/articles/time_012194.htm|title=Bodyguard Says Harding Knew of Plot|newspaper=Washington Post|first=Christine|last=Brennan|date=Jan 21, 1994|access-date=July 31, 2018}}{{cite news|newspaper=Seattle Post-Intelligencer|url=https://www.deseretnews.com/article/334609/RECORDS-INDICATE-HARDING-LIED-ABOUT-PHONE-CALLS.html|title=Records Indicate Harding Lied About Phone Calls|date=Feb 4, 1994|first=Angelo|last=Bruscas|accessdate=Aug 2, 2018}} It stated there was evidence Harding fraudulently used USFSA provided skating monies to finance the assault. It also read that Harding, Gillooly, Eckardt, Smith, and Stant agreed to "knowingly cause physical injury...by means of a dangerous weapon." The grand jury foreman said the evidence inferred Harding as "involved from the beginning or very close." She was not charged in the indictment due to the terms of her March 16 plea agreement.{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1994-03-22/sports/sp-36995_1_nancy-kerrigan|title=Indictment Says Harding Involved in Kerrigan Plot|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|agency=Associated Press|date=March 22, 1994|access-date=July 25, 2018}} On June 29, the USFSA disciplinary panel met for nine hours over two days to consider Harding's alleged role in the attack.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/06/30/sports/sports-people-figure-skating-harding-punishment-under-consideration.html|title=Harding Punishment Under Consideration|date=June 30, 1994|newspaper=New York Times|accessdate=Aug 11, 2018}} On June 30, chairman William Hybl stated "By a [[Burden of proof (law)|preponderance of the evidence]], the panel did conclude that she had prior knowledge and was involved prior to the incident. This is based on [[Civil procedure in the United States|civil standards]], not [[United States criminal procedure|criminal standards]]...bank records, phone records – the way they came together to establish a case." The panel decided that pertinent FBI reports, court documents, and Harding's March 16 plea agreement presented "a clear disregard for fairness, good sportsmanship, and ethical behaviour." Harding chose neither to attend nor participate in the two-day hearing. Robert Weaver said the decision disappointed her but was not a surprise, and that she had not decided on an appeal.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/longterm/olympics1998/history/timeline/articles/time_070194.htm|title=Harding Stripped of Title; Banned for Life|first=Christine |last=Brennan |newspaper=Washington Post |date=July 1, 1994 |accessdate=June 24, 2018}} Harding was stripped of the 1994 U.S. Championship title and banned for life from participating in USFSA events as either skater or coach. The USFSA has no dominion over professional skating events, yet Harding was also ''[[persona non grata]]'' on the pro circuit, few skaters and promoters would work with her. She did not benefit from the ensuing boom in professional skating after the scandal.{{sfn|Hamilton|Benet|1999|pages=558, 585}} Shortly before the [[1998 Winter Olympics]], the [[CBS News|CBS]] and [[Fox Sports|Fox]] news divisions re-examined the scandal for two televised [[special report]]s.{{cite news|url=https://archive.nytimes.com/www.nytimes.com/specials/olympics/nagano/021798oly-tv-sports.html|title=TV Sports: CBS Provides Entertaining Moments|first=Richard|last=Sandomir|newspaper=New York Times|date=Feb 17, 1998 |accessdate=July 6, 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://apnews.com/2778394bd828127ee9f32fb76299fa55 |title=Nancy & Tonya, Together|first=J|last=Dubow |newspaper=AP|date=1998-02-05|accessdate=2018-07-04}} [[Harry Smith (American journalist)|Harry Smith]] hosted the CBS special. He reported that Harding still held to her statement from her press-conference given on January 27, 1994: "I had no prior knowledge of the planned assault on Nancy Kerrigan." Smith then interviewed Kerrigan, asking how she responded to that statement. Nancy Kerrigan referred to transcripts she had read from Harding's FBI interview on January 18, 1994. After reading through the interrogation of that day, she concluded that "[Tonya] knew more than she admits."{{cite magazine|url=https://www.si.com/vault/1994/03/07/130609/silver-belle-nancy-kerrigan-conquered-her-demons-but-couldnt-overcome-a-pixie-from-ukraine|first=E. M.|last=Swift|title=Silver Belle|magazine=Sports Illustrated |date=1994-03-07|accessdate=2018-07-07}}{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/sports/1994/02/05/a-case-of-he-said-she-said/e85b11fd-e964-40f8-a3f6-1196083d2dd5/|title=A Case of He Said, She Said|first=Stephen|last=Buckley|newspaper=Washington Post |date=Feb 5, 1994|accessdate=2018-07-06}} The Fox special report was called ''Breaking the Ice: The Women of '94 Revisited'', hosted by [[James Brown (sportscaster)|James Brown]] with interviews from Harding, Gillooly, and Kerrigan.{{cite news|url=https://newsok.com/article/2601780/fox-relives-figure-skating-feud-tonight|title=Fox Relives Figure Skating Feud Tonight|first=Mel|last=Bracht|newspaper=The Oklahoman|date=Feb 5, 1998|accessdate=July 6, 2018}} Jeff Gillooly (granted a [[name change]] to Jeff Stone in 1995){{cite news |url=http://www.spokesman.com/stories/1995/jul/22/man-who-clubbed-kerrigan-skates-from-jail-former/ |title=Man Who Clubbed Kerrigan Skates From Jail Former Cda Strongman Stant Says He's Sorry For Attack|newspaper=Spokesman-Review|date=July 22, 1995|accessdate=2018-07-04}} said Harding's prison evasion did not anger him, and that he felt his own punishment was just. Stone reflected on Harding's position of "limited involvement" in Kerrigan's attack and speculated that a "guilty conscience" still troubled her. Brown then mediated a joint interview with both Kerrigan and Harding present. The two former competitors shared sincere desires for happy families and general well-wishes toward one other. Nancy Kerrigan said she hoped Harding could learn from past mistakes and "find happiness."{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/sports/1998/02/08/for-openers-many-eyes-were-closed/2f226bf6-6cb3-422c-9ffe-d1c55790b5b6/|title=For Openers, Many Eyes were Closed|first=Leonard|last=Shapiro |newspaper=Washington Post |date=Feb 8, 1998 |accessdate=July 5, 2018}} Harding said she was grateful to personally express remorse to Kerrigan again.{{cite news|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1998-02-06/sports/9802060057_1_harding-and-kerrigan-harding-s-ex-husband-nancy-kerrigan |title=Harding's Apology Rejected|first=Sharon|last=Robb |newspaper=Sun-Sentinel |date=Feb 6, 1998 |accessdate=July 5, 2018}} In Harding's 2008 biography, ''The Tonya Tapes'' (transcribed by Lynda D. Prouse from recorded interviews), she stated that she wanted to call the FBI in 1994 to reveal what she knew, but decided not to when Gillooly allegedly threatened her with death following a gunpoint gang rape by him and two other men she did not know. Jeff (Gillooly) Stone responded with surprise that groundless claims against him could be published and specifically contended her gang rape accusation to be "utterly ridiculous."{{cite web|url=https://www.today.com/news/tonya-harding-reveals-her-side-roller-coaster-life-1C9015579 |title=Tonya Harding reveals her side of 'roller-coaster life'|date=May 15, 2008|first=Mike|last=Celizic |accessdate=July 4, 2018|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170901024350/https://www.today.com/news/tonya-harding-reveals-her-side-roller-coaster-life-1C9015579|archivedate=2017-09-01}} In 2013, ''[[Deadspin]]'' sought Jeff Stone for an interview and he again defended himself from the gunpoint gang rape allegation. Yet he expressed regret that Harding is often "remembered for what I talked her into doing," meaning allegedly plotting to injure Nancy Kerrigan.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/02/sports/figure-skating-what-gillooly-says-and-what-harding-says.html|title=What Gillooly Says, and What Harding Says |first=Joseph B. |last=Treaster |newspaper=New York Times |date=Feb 2, 1994|accessdate=2018-06-22}}{{cite magazine |url=https://www.si.com/vault/1994/02/14/130460/anatomy-of-a-plot-even-in-their-version-of-events----which-differs-from-tonya-hardings----the-confessed-conspirators-in-the-nancy-kerrigan-assault-were-at-once-goons-and-buffoons |first=E. M. |last=Swift |title=Anatomy of a Plot |magazine=Sports Illustrated|date=Feb 14, 1994|accessdate=2016-11-28}}{{cite magazine |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140226105257/https://lostangelesca.tumblr.com/post/10912671075/whats-more-fun-than-a-good-old-fashioned-tonya-harding|archivedate=2014-02-26|url=https://lostangelesca.tumblr.com/post/10912671075/whats-more-fun-than-a-good-old-fashioned-tonya-harding|deadurl=yes|first=Randall|last=Sullivan|title=The Tonya Harding Fall|magazine=Rolling Stone|date=July 14, 1994|issue=686/687|page=80|url-access=registration|via=EBSCOhost|quote=Jeff saw [Tonya] for the first time in six days on...Jan. 25...loading their furniture into the bed of the blue Ford pickup. Tonya told him, "I just want you to know that I really do appreciate you taking the blame for all this," Jeff recalled, then asked for a hug. The FBI already had enough to arrest her, Jeff warned. They couldn't prove anything, Tonya replied. She said, "Good luck," Jeff recalled, squeezed his hand, gave him a wink and left. It was the last time he saw her.|accessdate=2018-08-29}} Stone admitted that his past stupidity was part of Harding's 1994 ruin and maintained that he still considered her a great figure skater. He also said "I've had it easy, compared to poor Tonya...she tends to be the butt of the joke. It's kind of sad to me."{{cite news |url=https://deadspin.com/finding-gillooly-what-happened-to-figure-skatings-inf-1482669790 |title=Finding Gillooly|last=Nelson |first=Amy K. |date=Dec 13, 2013|access-date=2018-06-21}} In 2014, Nancy Kerrigan addressed the scandal during a brief interview with sportscaster [[Bob Costas]]: "Whatever apology Tonya has given, I accept it. It's time for all us – I've always wished [Tonya] well – she has her own family, I have my family. It's time to make that our focus and move on with our lives."[https://sportsworld.nbcsports.com/nancy-tonya/]. ''NBC SportsWorld''. ''Nancy & Tonya'' (2014) documentary. The night's performance included [[Art Barr]] and [[Eddie Guerrero]].{{sfn|Guerrero|2005|pages=100–1}} A promotional musical event was unsuccessful when Harding and her band, the Golden Blades, were booed off the stage at their only performance, in 1995 in Portland, Oregon.{{cite magazine |url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20101626,00.html |title=Stage Fright|magazine=People|date=1995-09-18 |accessdate=2013-04-19|number=12 |volume=44}}{{cite news |url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19950830&slug=2139013 |title=Tonya Harding Debuts As Singer In Portland Concert For MDA |newspaper=Seattle Times |date=Aug 30, 1995 |accessdate=2013-04-19}} In 1994, Harding was cast in a low-budget action film, ''Breakaway''. Harding's boxing career came about amid rumors that she was having financial difficulties and needed to fight in the ring to earn money.{{cite news |title=Tonya Harding Loses in Pro Boxing Debut |url=http://www.ourmidland.com/news/article/Tonya-Harding-Loses-in-Pro-Boxing-Debut-7070027.php |first=Barry |last=Wilner |date=Feb 21, 2003 |newspaper=Midland Daily News}} She did another celebrity boxing match, on ''[[The Man Show]]'', and won against co-host [[Doug Stanhope]]. Stanhope later claimed on his podcast that the fight was fixed because Tonya Harding refused to "fight a man."{{cite web |url=http://stanhope.libsyn.com/ep-22-comedian-andy-andrist-pt2 |title=Ep. #22: Comedian Andy Andrist - Pt.2 |website=The Doug Stanhope Podcast |accessdate=June 5, 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160808143606/http://stanhope.libsyn.com/ep-22-comedian-andy-andrist-pt2 |archivedate=August 8, 2016 }} On March 23, 2004, it was reported that she canceled a planned boxing match against Tracy Carlton in [[Oakland, California]], because of an alleged death threat against her.{{cite news |title=Why Harding wasn't in bout / Manager cites death threats, skills of foe |url=http://www.sfgate.com/sports/article/Why-Harding-wasn-t-in-bout-Manager-cites-death-2777303.php |first=Dwight |last=Chapin |date=March 23, 2004 |accessdate=2017-12-28|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle}} On June 24, 2004, after reportedly not having boxed for over a year, she was beaten in a match in [[Edmonton]], Alberta, by Amy Johnson. She gave birth to her only child, a son named Gordon, on February 19, 2011.{{cite magazine |url=http://celebritybabies.people.com/2011/02/23/tonya-harding-welcomes-a-son/#more-126909 |title=Tonya Harding welcomes a son |date=Feb 23, 2011 |first=Mike |last=Fleeman |magazine=People |accessdate=2011-02-27}} Since leaving skating and boxing, Harding has worked as a welder, a painter at a metal fabrication company, and a hardware sales clerk at Sears.{{cite news |last1=Brodesser-Akner |first1=Taffy |authorlink=Taffy Brodesser-Akner |title=Tonya Harding Would Like Her Apology Now |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/10/movies/tonya-harding-i-tonya-nancy-kerrigan-scandal.html |accessdate=2018-01-10|newspaper=New York Times |date=2018-01-10}} As of 2017, she stated that she worked as a painter and deck builder.{{cite av media|title=I, Tonya|people=Gillespie, Craig (dir.)|year=2017|publisher=Neon Films}} She resides in [[Washington (state)|Washington]] state, north of her hometown of Portland, Oregon. On an appearance on ''[[The Ellen DeGeneres Show]]'' on February 26, 2018, Harding stated that she is still active in skating and practices three times a week. In a segment during the show, she performed several jumps and spins. She trains with her former coach, Dody Teachman.{{cite web|title=Tonya Harding on her continued love for figure skating & what her life is like today|author1=Rakowski, Cat |author2= Valiente, Alexa|date=Jan 11, 2018|accessdate=2018-02-05|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/tonya-harding-continued-love-figure-skating-life-today/story?id=52260238|work=ABC News}} == Cultural significance == Harding still receives criticism.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/columnist/brennan/2017/12/20/tonya-harding-movie-wants-your-sympathy-but-lets-not-forget-facts/971183001/|title=Tonya Harding movie wants your sympathy, but let's not forget the facts|first=Christine|last=Brennan |newspaper=USA Today|date=December 20, 2017|accessdate=July 26, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://deadspin.com/how-much-sympathy-does-tonya-harding-deserve-1822095036|title=How Much Sympathy Does Tonya Harding Deserve?|website=Deadspin|first=Dvora|last=Meyers|date=January 17, 2018|accessdate=July 26, 2018}}{{cite magazine |url=https://people.com/movies/tonya-harding-was-involved-up-to-her-neck-in-the-nancy-kerrigan-attack-says-oregon-da/|first=Mia|last=McNiece|title=Tonya Harding 'Was Involved Up to Her Neck' in the Nancy Kerrigan Attack, Says Oregon DA|publisher=Meredith Corporation|magazine=People|date=January 31, 2018|accessdate=July 26, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.oregonlive.com/trending/2018/01/i_nauseated_the_oregonians_for.html|title='I, Nauseated': The Oregonian's ex-sports columnist nails what the Tonya Harding movie gets wrong|first=J.E.|last=Vader|newspaper=[[The Oregonian]]|date=Jan 29, 2018|accessdate=July 26, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.oregonlive.com/portland/index.ssf/2018/02/i_was_tonya_hardings_prosecuto.html|title='I, Tonya'? Well, I prosecuted. And Tonya Harding was guilty as charged|first=Norm|last=Frink|newspaper=[[The Oregonian]]|date=February 24, 2018 |accessdate=July 26, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2018/07/falling-out-of-love-with-tonya-harding.html#|title=Falling Out of Love With Tonya Harding|website=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]|first=Jamie|last=Loftus|date=July 19, 2018 |accessdate=July 26, 2018}} However, her life, career, and role in the Kerrigan attack have been widely referenced in popular culture; appearing in television, film, music, as well as a [[Democratic Party (United States) presidential primaries, 2008|primary campaign]] speech by former President [[Barack Obama]].{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/deadlineusa/2009/mar/04/tonya-harding-barack-obama-name-kneecap |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |title=Tonya Harding bitter and thankful over Obama's 'kneecap' comment |date=March 4, 2009 |accessdate=May 25, 2010 |first=Paul |last=Lester}} In 2014, Matt Harkins and Viviana Olen created the Nancy Kerrigan and Tonya Harding Museum in their [[Brooklyn, New York]], apartment, dedicated to collecting and archiving memorabilia related to Harding and the incident.{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/2015/04/19/400736119/like-dynasty-on-ice-the-nancy-kerrigan-and-tonya-harding-museum |title=Like 'Dynasty' On Ice: The Nancy Kerrigan And Tonya Harding Museum |website=NPR |date=April 19, 2015 |accessdate=Dec 28, 2016}} Harkins and Olen stated in a 2017 interview that they had been captivated by Harding's life for years, citing it as "the most American story ever told."{{cite web|work=Vulture|title=Cult of Tonya Harding|date=Dec 6, 2017|accessdate=January 18, 2018|url=http://www.vulture.com/2017/12/the-cult-of-tonya-harding.html|author1=Olen, Viviana |author2= Harkins, Matt}} A contemporaneous article published in ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'' also noted that Harding had developed a "[[cult following]]" in the years since her notoriety.{{cite web|url=https://www.vogue.com/article/fashion-runway-i-tonya-costumes-90s-fashion|work=Vogue|title=I, Tonya's Costume Designer on Why She Didn't Want to Take a Cheap Shot at '90s Fashion|author=Bobb, Brooke|date=Dec 8, 2017|accessdate=January 30, 2018}} === Representation in other media === * ''Sharp Edges'' (1986), filmmaker Sandra Luckow's senior-thesis project documentary for her [[Film studies]] major at [[Yale University]]. Luckow was Harding's childhood friend, and the documentary followed Harding and her coaches to [[Uniondale, New York]] as she competed in the February [[1986 U.S. Figure Skating Championships]]. The film featured interviews with Harding, her mother and coaches, discussing her career in figure skating.{{cite magazine|last=Gleiberman|first=Owen|title=Film Review: The 1986 Tonya Harding Documentary ‘Sharp Edges’|url=https://variety.com/2018/film/reviews/film-review-sharp-edges-tonya-harding-1986-1202865442/|accessdate=August 12, 2018|magazine=Variety|date=July 4, 2018}} * ''Spunk: The Tonya Harding Story'' (1994), [[Comedy Central]] five-minute [[short film]] [[parody]] summarizing the scandal, estimated to have aired on February 25, 1994.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0195301/releaseinfo?|title=Spunk: Tonya Harding Story - Release Dates|website=IMDb|accessdate=2018-08-28}} [[Tina Yothers]] portrayed Harding as perpetually misunderstood, but universally admired for her "spunk." * [[Tonya and Nancy: The Inside Story|''Tonya & Nancy: The Inside Story'' (1994)]], NBC [[television film]] based on [[public domain]] material, premiered on April 30, 1994; directed by [[Larry Shaw (director)|Larry Shaw]] and written by previous [[Edgar Award]] winner Phil Penningroth.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0672150/awards?|title=Phil Penningroth - Awards|website=IMDb|accessdate=July 18, 2018}} [[Alexandra Powers]] portrayed Harding and [[Heather Langenkamp]] portrayed Nancy Kerrigan. It featured a [[Postmodernism|postmodern]] breaking of the [[fourth wall]] by having [[Dennis Boutsikaris]] play the film's screenwriter, addressing the audience over the course of the story. One of the last lines in the film was "We imprisoned [Tonya and Nancy] in images we use to sell newspapers, soup, and TV movies. They're victims of those that the media serve."{{Cite web|url=https://variety.com/1994/tv/reviews/tonya-nancy-the-inside-story-1200436535/|title=Tonya & Nancy: The Inside Story|last=Loynd|first=Ray|date=April 29, 1994|website=Variety|access-date=2018-09-13}} * [[Attack of the 5 Ft. 2 In. Brown's original song for the segment, "Queen of the Ice," was nominated for a [[CableACE Award]].{{cite web|url=http://ew.com/article/1994/08/19/national-lampoons-attack-52-women/|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|title=National Lampoon's Attack of the 5'2" Women|accessdate=Dec 30, 2017|date=Aug 19, 1994 |author=Schwarzbaum, Lisa}}{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0109167/awards?|title=Attack of the 5 Ft. 2 In.
